2's game engine has a lot of weird and
unique quirks to it one of them being
that level design is not done in engine
with brushes but is instead done in
traditional modeling tools like 3ds max
or blender this has its advantages and
disadvantages of course but I quite like
it as a whole I find working on simple
meshes like this really relaxing most
the time so now it's time to begin
modeling our map I find the best place
to start is generally to create the
terrain first this gives me a really
good idea of the maps overall shape and
from there I can fill in the cliff faces
and then seal the map entirely sealing
is very important as the map has to be a
single sealed interior mesh with no open
edges duplicate triangles or degenerate
faces any of these kinds of errors can
result in unexpected behavior or
collision problems in game once the
sealing is done we can export the model
to its proprietary
ass format and import it into halo too
and if you just so happen to be using
the original export plugin instead of

for the map ground textures in Halo are
another interesting quirk of the game
that I think deserves to own explanation
so for an example here is the ground
texture for coagulation as you can see
it's a rather small texture it only 512
pixels squared but it's used for the
entire Canyon the way this works is that
the ground texture is actually blended
with multiple other grayscale detail
textures with the Alpha Channel of the
ground texture acting as a mask to
interpolate between the different detail
textures the result of this is that you
get the color of the ground texture
mixed into the tile detail textures
creating a rather nice looking effect
that is very efficient to render the
downside of this is that I'm absolutely
[ __ ] terrible painting textures so I

know at least the basics of how 3d

individually made up of three vertices
which consists of three floating-point
values representing the x y&z position
in 3d space but that only defines its

is determined by the physical surface
below the water so what you have to do
is split your terrain into two separate
shaders one to use for the dry ground
and the other for the wet ground you
then have to go into that shader and
assign a collision material for one of
the various liquid types now you have
water that is actually water
